Award.AwardTitle: PPoSS: Planning: Dynamic Big Graph Store for High-Throughput and Secure Distributed Query Processing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Since graphs can readily express entities and relationships among them, they are widely used to represent large volumes of data from domains ranging from online shopping platforms to social networks. These graphs continue to evolve in size and structure as they integrate new data that emerges, often in real time, thus creating a need for online analytics to answer user queries based upon the latest available information. The goal of this research is to address fundamental challenges across the software-hardware spectrum to develop a scalable and secure distributed platform for online graph analytics. This research will discover novel techniques for delivering meaningful answers to queries over changing data, with a high degree of efficiency, while addressing security concerns that can arise in cloud settings. The key components of this platform, named DyGr, include: a graph store with a consistency model that tailors the scope of consistency to efficiently compute meaningful answers to queries; an event-driven incremental computation model that is supported across software and hardware layers to rapidly compute query results; and hardware supported protocols for secure distributed evaluation of queries over private data. <br/><br/>By building of a powerful online analytics system this research will contribute to acceleration of new discoveries in fields that employ graph analytics. Advances in online analytics will enable new applications that are relevant to businesses and thus will contribute to economic growth. The students participating in this project will gain comprehensive training in all aspects of system building as well as receive training in applications that require online analytics. Therefore, the broader impact in form of contributions to workforce development in an area of national need will be tremendous.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Data in many domains is represented in form of large graphs (e.g., internet topology, social networks) and graph analytics involves analyzing and mining these graphs to answer user queries, also called graph queries. In this work we developed a system for rapidly evaluating answers to multiple queries being received from users. To build a high throughput distributed graph query evaluation system this project developed multiple complimentary approaches.

First, techniques for simultaneously evaluating multiple graph queries were developed that are embodied in our BEAD system. Second, novel hardware accelerators named GraphPulse and JetStream were developed that can be deployed across a distributed system to speedup query evaluation. Third, we developed the Tripoline system for query evaluation that can not only evaluate queries over fixed graphs but also over dynamically changing graphs. Our experimental studies show that each of these techniques can deliver manyfold speedups and taken together they can enable very high throughput query evaluation.

Over the course of the above work multiple PhD students received valuable training in research and building of high-performance big data systems. They also published and presented papers at top conferences in their research area. The students made substantial progress towards their degree objectives. One PhD student successfully defended his dissertation and is joining a major vendor that builds high-performance platforms.
